title-group.article-title: Modeling of moisture evaporation from the skin, eyes, and airway to evaluate sensations of dryness in low-humidity environments

abstract.p: Occupants of low-humidity environments often complain of a sensation of dryness. According to the results of a questionnaire administered to 1000 Japanese office workers, 70% of that population experiences dryness during dry seasons. It is therefore important to clarify the environmental conditions that cause discomfort due to dryness and control the indoor environmental conditions to avoid such discomfort. For the purpose, this study aims at creating a numerical model to predict the sensation of dryness under certain environmental conditions. Since one of the causes of dryness would be the high evaporation rates from the body part where dryness is perceived, the modeling of moisture evaporation from the surface of skin, eyes, and airway was studied in this article, using the thermal model of human body. At the same time, the evaporation rates from the skin surface, eyes, and airway of a human were calculated for various air temperatures and humidity levels. It was shown quantitatively from the calculated results that the air temperature as well as the vapor pressure influences the evaporation rate because the air temperature thermally influences the temperature of the surface where evaporation occurs (skin, eyes, and throat).

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Occupants of low-humidity environments often complain of dryness. According to an Internet survey (Takada et al., 2010) of Japanese office workers, 70% of these individuals have “often” or “sometimes” experienced discomfort due to dryness in their office environments, especially during dry seasons (winter in Japan). These individuals have reported that they sense this dryness mostly in the throat, followed by the lips, eyes, and face (Figure 1). Thus, the mechanism by which the discomfort due to dryness occurs must be clarified to properly control indoor environments in dry climates. One cause of dryness is an increase in the evaporation rate of moisture from the body part where dryness is being perceived. Dryness is frequently considered to be related to indoor humidity, but the evaporation rate of moisture from the human body is determined not only by the vapor pressure of the ambient air but also by the temperature and air velocity on the surface where evaporation is occurring. Moreover, the surface temperature is influenced by environmental factors such as air temperature, humidity, radiant temperature, and air velocity. Therefore, there are various alternatives to humidification to alleviate discomfort due to dryness.

caption.p: Questionnaire answered by 1000 Japanese office workers via the Internet: the respondents belonged to the population working in the urban region on the main island of Japan, half in the Kansai area (Osaka, Hyogo, Kyoto, Shiga, Nara, and Wakayama prefectures) and the other half in the Kanto area (Tokyo, Kanagawa, Chiba, Saitama, Ibaraki, Gunma, and Tochigi prefectures). (a) Question 1: Have you ever felt discomfort due to excessive dryness of the air while working in the office? (N = 1000). (b) Question 2: During which season do you feel the most discomfort due to excessive dryness of the air while working in the office? (N = 727). (c) Question 3: On which parts of the body do you sense discomfort due to dryness most often while working in the office? Select one (N = 727).

sec.p: Several experimental approaches to evaluate the human response to low humidity have been reported (Karaki et al., 2004; Tsutsumi et al., 2007), but few theoretical studies have focused on causative factors other than humidity. This study proposes a numerical model to predict moisture evaporation rates from skin, eye, and airway surfaces based on a thermal model of the human body, and the calculated surface evaporation rates were plotted on a psychrometric chart to demonstrate the influence of ambient temperature and humidity on dryness. For the skin, moisture diffusion through the horny layer is evaluated. For the eye, a model of moisture evaporation based on tears present on the eye surface is proposed, and the relationship between the surface temperatures of the eye and face is discussed based on the measured data. For the airway, a heat and moisture transfer model in the airway was developed based on the thermal capacitance of the airway wall and the distribution of temperature and humidity in the airway from the nose/mouth to the lungs.

sec.title: Outline of a model for predicting the evaporation rate from the skin, eye, and throat
sec.p: The moisture resistances and vapor pressures at the surfaces of the skin, eye, and throat were defined, respectively, as shown in Figure 2, using the following assumptions. Liquid water would exist near the surface of the three considered body parts. For the skin, the liquid water evaporates through the horny layer, which acts as a moisture barrier. For the eye, because tears consist of three layers (mucin layer on the eyeball surface, liquid layer on top of the mucin layer, and oil layer at the air surface), it is assumed that liquid evaporates through the oil layer, which acts as a moisture barrier. For the throat, the surface of the airway is always saturated with liquid water. For each of the three parts, if the temperature of the saturated surface and the moisture resistance of the barrier (except for the throat) are known, the evaporation rate can be predicted, neglecting the moisture capacitance of the barrier, by equation (1) for the skin and eyes and by equation (2) for the throat.

The original Stolwijk (1971) model sets the evaporation rate due to diffusion through skin at a constant value, which is shown in equation (1). psat is calculated using the temperature of the saturated surface; the temperature is determined based on the calculation by Stolwijk model. The Stolwijk model is a human thermal model used to calculate the temperature distribution throughout the entire body (described in detail in Appendix 1); the thermal environmental conditions, that is, air temperature, humidity, air velocity, radiant temperature, clothing, and metabolism, are inputted into this model to determine this distribution (Figure 3).

sec.p: For the skin, the temperature at the saturated surface (under the horny layer) is assumed to be the same as the skin surface temperature, since the horny layer could be regarded as suitably thin (Zhen et al., 1999). For the eyes, the skin temperature of the head that is calculated by the model is used tentatively (described in detail in the “Discussion” section). For the throat, the surface temperature of the airway wall is calculated using the airway model (Figures 4 and 5, equations (4)–(14)). The airway model consists of the heat and moisture balance equations for air in the airway (equations (4)–(9)) and the two-dimensional heat conduction equation in the wall of the airway, which considers the heat capacitance of the airway wall (equations (10)–(14)). The shape of the airway is simplified to a column extending from the lungs to the openings at the mouth or nose, and a constant respiration rhythm of 6.0 L/min with a cycle of 6 s/breath was used (Zhu et al., 2004). The moisture flux at the surface of the airway at a depth of 12 cm from the nose/mouth is outputted to evaluate the dryness at the throat.

sec.title: Calculation conditions
sec.p: To encompass the indoor environment during the winter season, moisture evaporation rates were calculated for all possible combinations of indoor air temperature (15°C–30°C at increments of 0.5 K) and relative humidity (0%–100% at increments of 5%), with θmrt equal to air temperature, low air velocity, a clo value equal to 1.0, and an activity of 1 Met, in the steady state. The convective and radiative heat transfer coefficients around the human body (αc and αr) are taken as the default values reported by Stolwijk (1971). The insulation provided by clothing is accounted for as the thermal and moisture resistances at the skin surface in the calculation using the Stolwijk model (Figure 3).

The surface moisture transfer resistance R′s is given in Table 1. For the airway, R′s at the inner surface of the airway is determined based on a steady respiration cycle shown in Figure 5. The values in Table 2 are used in the airway model. The dimensions of the airway were determined based on anatomical knowledge.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The moisture evaporation rates at steady-state conditions are plotted on the psychrometric charts in Figures 6–8 for the skin of the head, the eyes, and the throat, respectively, along with the corresponding regulatory sweating rates. In general, the evaporation rate increases as the vapor pressure decreases and the air temperature increases. Skin with regulatory sweating is the exception: as the air temperature increases, the evaporation rate decreases due to an increase in the regulatory sweating rate. Sweating suppresses evaporation through the horny layer from a saturated surface, as shown in Figure 2. The evaporation rate at the eye (Figure 7) is much higher than that at the skin due to our tentative assumption that the moisture barrier provides zero resistance. After the real resistance of the oil layer of the tear is determined, this value will decrease, but the shape of the contour in Figure 7 will not change. For the throat (Figure 8), the influences of air temperature and vapor pressure on evaporation rate are greater than those for the skin and eye because the room air is inhaled directly into the airway. For the eye and the throat, no sweat is present at the locations at which the evaporation is evaluated, but the temperature is indirectly affected by the regulatory sweating, and the evaporation is, therefore, suppressed when the regulatory sweating is present.

sec.title: Skin
sec.p: The evaporation rate results for the skin were determined only for the head with a constant value for moisture resistance of the horny layer as a moisture barrier. However, the thickness of the horny layer is known to fluctuate depending on the area of the body being considered (Zhen et al., 1999). Moreover, the moisture capacitance of the horny layer, which is neglected in this article, should be studied further.

sec.title: Eye
sec.p: In this article, the surface temperature of the eye was assumed to be equal to the skin temperature of the head. As shown in Figures 9 and 10, the measured eye surface temperature is 0.6 K higher than the surface temperature averaged for the whole face under 21.6°C, 49%rh environment (Takada et al., 2011). Figure 11 shows that this tendency is clearer when the ambient air temperature is lower. Thus, it is necessary to develop a thermal model to predict the eye surface temperature. Furthermore, as described above, measuring the moisture resistance of the oil layer of tears is necessary to predict the evaporation rate at the eye (Tsubota et al., 1992). At the same time, the influence of blinking should be studied. Though not considered in the model of this article, the surface temperature of the eyes with contact lenses tends to be lower than that without contact lenses (Figures 9 and 10).

sec.title: Airway
sec.p: The calculated results of evaporation rates at the throat shown in Figure 8 are the solution in the periodic steady state. Due to the respiration rhythm considered, which includes a cycle of 6 s/breath, all the variables related to the airway (temperature and absolute humidity) fluctuate. The evaporation rate shown in Figure 8 is the averaged value for a cycle of the respiration. The air temperature in the airway under the ambient air of 25°C, 50%rh is shown in Figure 12. The temperature increases during exhalation (air flows from the lungs to the ambient) and decreases during inhalation. The air temperature in the airway depends on the airway wall that has a boundary condition of a given temperature at the depth of 10 mm from the surface of the airway (Figure 4). In this article, the wall temperature at the boundary was determined using the trunk fat temperature calculated by the Stolwijk model, which is affected by the outer air temperature. In addition, it is assumed that the entire surface of the airway is saturated under all conditions. Zhu et al. (2004) showed based on computational fluid dynamics (CFD) analysis that re-inhalation amounts to 17% of exhaled air, which is not considered in the calculation of this article. The validity of these assumptions should be evaluated by further measurements. The throat portion of the airway is evaluated in this article, but another output will be necessary for evaluating the dryness in the nose.

sec.title: Influence of air velocity
sec.p: Figures 6–8 show that the air temperature, as well as the absolute humidity, is an important factor that should be considered for evaluating the evaporation rate. This result suggests the possibility of decreasing the evaporation rates from the human body surfaces by controlling the room air temperature as well as the humidity. The air velocity around the human body is also a factor in determining the evaporation rate that is reflected in the moisture transfer coefficient, especially for the eyes and the skin. In this article, the value of moisture transfer coefficient (converted from the convective heat transfer coefficient using Lewis relation) is set constant at the level of a calm airflow as shown in Table 1 to focus on the influence of the temperature. However, this issue should be studied further.

sec.title: Influence of clothing and metabolic rate
sec.p: The clothing insulation level used in the calculation of body temperature based on the Stolwijk model (Figure 3) was set constant at 1 clo. This use of a constant value is not a completely realistic assumption, and this condition can change over the range of environmental conditions for which the evaporation rates were predicted (as shown in Figures 6–8). It will be necessary to input realistic clothing insulation levels for the proposed model to provide a more precise prediction. At the same time, it should be noted that this assumption was not an unrealistic one in the business environment during winter.
The metabolic rate was set constant at 1 Met in the calculation of this article. In the phase of the prediction, a value for the targeted situation should be inputted.

sec.title: Relationship between the evaporation rate and sensation of dryness
sec.p: A survey of office workers indicated that these workers often experienced discomfort due to dryness primarily in their facial skin, eyes, and throats, as a result of the dry indoor climate to which they were subjected. Therefore, the moisture evaporation rates from the skin of head, eye, and throat were targeted for the modeling in this article, and the calculated results were reported. Further study is needed to examine the relationship between evaporation rate and discomfort due to dryness. If a correlation exists between these two factors, it may be possible to determine the limits of discomfort due to dryness based on the psychrometric chart contours as shown in Figures 6–8.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This study proposed a numerical model based on the human thermal model to predict moisture evaporation rates from the surface of the skin, eye, and airway, to establish a basis for evaluating the sensation of dryness experienced by occupants of low-humidity indoor environments. The moisture evaporation rates from the skin, eyes, and throat were determined based on the moisture flux from the saturated surfaces of these body parts (the bottom of the horny layer of the skin, the bottom of the oil layer of tears in the eyes, and the surface of airway wall in the throat), and the temperatures of the saturated surfaces were determined using the Stolwijk model (a human thermal model) by inputting the thermal environmental conditions of a room. A heat and moisture transfer model for the airway was used to determine the evaporation rates from the throat that considered both the thermal capacitance of the airway wall and the distribution of temperature and humidity in the airway between the nose/mouth and the lungs.

The results calculated using the proposed model for sedentary conditions in indoor spaces showed that the air temperature as well as the vapor pressure influences the evaporation rates significantly because the air temperature thermally influences the temperature of the saturated surface where evaporation occurs (skin, eyes, and throat). These results indicated the possibility of decreasing the evaporation rate from the human body surface by controlling not only humidity but also the ambient temperature of the room. In addition, the influence of the suppression of the evaporation by the perspiration of the regulatory sweating was also demonstrated quantitatively, and this phenomenon has a direct influence on the skin and an indirect influence on the eyes and throats.

sec.title: Basic equations of Stolwijk model
sec.p: The Stolwijk model is one of the human thermal models that has provided a partial basis and inspiration for many human thermal modeling studies. The validity of the Stolwijk model has been demonstrated based on a comparison between the calculated and measured results of experiments on human subjects (Munir et al., 2009; Stolwijk, 1971).

The Stolwijk model (Figure 13) comprises six segments: the head, trunk, arms, hands, legs, and feet. Each of these segments is divided into four layers: the core, muscle, fat, and skin.
